column1: Orange is a city in the Central Tablelands region of New South Wales
column2: Australia. It is 254 km (158 mi) west of the state capital
column3: Sydney [206 km (128 mi) on a great circle]
column4: at an altitude of 862 metres (2
column5: 828 ft). Orange had an estimated urban population of 40
column6: 493 as of June 2018 making the city a significant regional centre. A significant nearby landmark is Mount Canobolas with a peak elevation of 1
column8: 577 ft) AHD  and commanding views of the district.

column1: Orange is the birthplace of poets Banjo Paterson and Kenneth Slessor
column2: although Paterson lived in Orange for only a short time as an infant. Walter W. Stone
column3: book publisher (Wentworth Books) and passionate supporter of Australian literature
column4: was also born in Orange. The first Australian Touring Car Championship
column5: known today as V8 Supercar Championship Series
column6: was held at the Gnoo Blas Motor Racing Circuit in 1960.

column1: In 1822 Captain Percy Simpson marched into the Wellington District and established a convict settlement which was called "Blackman's Swamp" after James Blackman; Simpson had employed James Blackman as a guide because he had already accompanied an earlier explorer
column2: John Oxley into that region.In the late 1820s
column3: the surveyor J. B. Richards worked on a survey of the Macquarie River below Bathurst and also of the road to Wellington. On a plan dated 1829
column4: he indicated a village reserve
column5: in the parish of Orange. Sir Thomas Mitchell named the parish Orange
column6: as he had been an associate of the Prince of Orange in the Peninsular War
column7: when both were aides-de-camp to the Duke of Wellington
column8: whose title was bestowed on the valley to the west by Oxley.Initial occupation by British graziers began in late 1829
column9: and tiny settlements eventually turned into larger towns as properties came into connection with the road. In 1844
column10: the surveyor Davidson was sent to check on encroachments onto the land reserved for a village
column11: and to advise on the location for a township. His choices were Frederick's Valley

column2: and it was proclaimed a village and named Orange by Major Thomas Mitchell in 1846 in honour of Prince William of Orange. At nearby Ophir
column3: a significant gold find in Australia was made in 1851
column4: resulting in a sporadic population movement which is known as the Australian gold rush. Additional gold finds in nearby areas led to the establishment of Orange as a central trading centre for the gold.

column1: The growth of Orange continued as the conditions were well suited for agriculture
column2: and in 1860 it was proclaimed a municipality. The railway from Sydney reached Orange in 1877. In 1946
column3: 100 years after it was first being established as a village
column4: Orange was proclaimed as a minor city.

column1: According to the 2016 census of Population
column3: 182 people in the Orange urban centre.

column1: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 6.6% of the population.
83.2% of people were born in Australia. The next most common countries of birth were England 1.6%
column4: Philippines 0.5% and China 0.4%.

column1: 87.3% of people only spoke English at home. Other languages spoken at home included Malayalam 0.7%
The most common responses for religion were Catholic 30.1%
Of the employed people in Orange (Urban Centres and Localities)
column2: 6.2% worked in hospitals (except psychiatric hospitals). Other major industries of employment included gold ore mining 4.2%
column4: other social assistance services 3.2% and supermarket and grocery Stores 2.5%.

column2: Orange has a temperate oceanic climate (Köppen Cfb)
column3: with warm summers (though with cool mornings) and cool winters with frequent morning frosts and light to moderate
column4: sometimes heavy snowfalls. The city is relatively wet for an inland location owing to orographic effects from Mount Canobolas
column5: especially during the cooler months when snow falls; Orange is amongst the few cities in Australia to receive regular snowfall
column6: and is likewise the snowiest city in Australia (not counting smaller towns such as Oberon). Due to its windward position that straddles the Great Dividing Range
column7: Orange experiences wetter winters than the cities in the east such as Lithgow and Bathurst.

column1: Compared with most population centres in Australia it has colder winters
column2: especially in terms of its daytime maximum temperatures
column3: owing chiefly to its south-westerly exposure. In summer
column4: the average (and absolute) maximum temperatures are also lower than in most inland centres
column5: on account of its elevation. Owing to its inland location
column6: the humidity is low in the summer months with the dewpoint typically around 10 °C. Having 99.8 clear days annually
column7: it is still cloudier than the coastal areas of Sydney and Wollongong (104 and 107 clear days
column9: with a marked lack of sunshine in winter compared to summer.The climate has enabled the area to be a major apple and pear producer
column10: and more recently a centre for cool-weather wine production.

column1: Orange is a well-known fruit growing district
column4: and many stone fruits such as cherries
column5: peaches
column7: and plums; oranges are not grown in the area
column8: since its climate is too cool. In recent years
column9: a large number of vineyards have been planted in the area for rapidly expanding wine production. The growth of this wine industry
column10: coupled with the further development of Orange as a gourmet food capital
column11: has ensured Orange's status as a prominent tourism destination.

column1: Cadia gold mine is a large open cut gold and copper mine located about 20 kilometres south of Orange. The mine has been developed throughout the 1990s and is a major employer in the region with an expected lifespan of several decades. Cadia is the second largest open-cut mine in Australia
column2: following the Super Pit at Kalgoorlie
column3: Western Australia. Large mineral deposits are also being uncovered from the more recently developed Ridgeway underground mine which is adjacent to the Cadia Mine.

column2: closed in 2017.Orange is also the location of the headquarters of the New South Wales Department of Industry (Department of Industry
column4: the New South Wales Department of Primary Industries).

Cadia-Ridgeway Mine is a large open cut gold and copper mine located about 20 kilometres south of Orange
column2: the mine has been developed throughout the 1990s employing several thousand employees with an expected lifespan of several decades. Cadia is the second largest open cut mine in Australia after the Super Pit at Kalgoorlie. Large mineral deposits are also being uncovered from the more recently developed Ridgeway underground mine which is adjacent to the Cadia Mine.

column1: The Orange wine region is defined as the area above 600m in the local government areas of Orange
column2: Cabonne and Blayney and can be usefully described as a circle around Orange. The Orange region is good for grape growing and winemaking due to a combination of geology
column4: climate and temperature. Together these factors combine to produce grapes and wine of distinct flavours and colour. The climate perhaps plays the biggest part in giving Orange some distinct natural advantages – the cool temperatures during most of the growing season coupled with dry autumn conditions are ideal for grape growing.

column1: Wineries that use Orange region grapes in their wines include Brokenwood Wines (Hunter Valley based)
column4: Gartelmann (Hunter Valley)
column5: Windowrie (Central Ranges)
column6: Eloquesta Wines (Mudgee) and Lowe Wines (Mudgee).  In 2007
column7: South Australian based Penfolds winery released the 2007 Penfolds Bin 311 Orange Region Chardonnay.

column1: Of the three main commercial networks:
Prime7 News produces a half-hour local news bulletin for the Central West
column2: airing each weeknight at 6pm. It is produced from local newsrooms in Orange and Dubbo and broadcast from studios in Canberra.

column1: Southern Cross Nine airs a regional New South Wales edition of Nine News from Sydney each weeknight at 6pm
column2: featuring opt-outs for the Central West.

column1: WIN Television aired a half-hour local bulletin until the closure of its Orange newsroom in June 2019. The station now produces short news updates throughout the day from its Wollongong studios.Subscription television service Foxtel is available in Orange and the surrounding region via satellite.
The local newspapers are the Central Western Daily
column2: the Midstate Observer and Orange City Life.

column1: Orange has several water sources used for domestic consumption
column2: both currently in use and formerly used. Currently Suma Park Dam and Spring Creek Reservoir are used for domestic water consumption. Two other dams
column3: Lake Canobolas and Gosling Creek Reservoir
column4: were previously used for domestic water consumption; however
column5: they are now used for recreational purposes. The city is currently on Level 2 water restrictions
column6: following good rain (Sept 2020).  Orange City Council is undertaking a number of strategies to supplement its supply

column1: The first batch of harvested stormwater was released into Suma Park Dam on 21 April 2009. The harvested stormwater was tested by Analytical Laboratory Services
column2: an independent laboratory based in Sydney. ALS tested for 90 potential pollutants. The tests revealed that the water quality met all targets. The first batch contained 14 megalitres. It is believed to be an Australian first for harvesting stormwater for potable use. The hardware is in place
column3: operating rules have been developed and environmental factors and impacts on downstream users have been considered. A three-month trial will ensure all these elements are working together to ensure high water quality and environmental standards are met. There are several phases involved in the commissioning period. The hardware
column4: which includes three separate pumping stations
column5: creek flow monitoring points and advanced electronics including fibre optic cables
column6: will undergo further operating tests. The other elements of the scheme include a weir on Blackmans Swamp Creek
column7: which creates a 3 megalitre pool and the site for the first pump station
column8: a 200 megalitre dam and two 17 megalitre batching ponds. The pumps on the creek transfer stormwater to the 200 megalitre dam at a rate of up to 450 litres per second and are designed to rapidly extract peak storm flows from the creek. The operating rules require that a base flow immediately downstream in the creek must be maintained. The creek flow monitoring points ensure these standards are met. The monitoring station also measures when harvesting can commence. The trigger is flows passing the monitor in Blackmans Swamp Creek exceeding 1000 litres per second.

column3: uses the city's treated effluent to supplement its water supply.

column1: Orange is currently planning to implement a pipeline from the Macquarie river to boost the town water supply. This is hotly debated
column2: and researchers believe that it will endanger threatened wetland areas.

column4: opened in 1970
